title-group.article-title: Enamel Lesion Parameter Correlations between Polychromatic Micro-CT and TMR

article-meta.aff: 1Cariology and Operative Dentistry, Department of Restorative Sciences, Graduate School of Medical and Dental Sciences, Tokyo Medical and Dental University, Tokyo, 1-5-45, Yushima, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113-8549, Japan
2Global Center of Excellence (GCOE) Program, International Research Center for Molecular Science in Tooth and Bone Diseases at Tokyo Medical and Dental University, Tokyo, Japan

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: Transverse microradiography (TMR) is considered as the gold standard technique for the evaluation of enamel lesions. Micro-computed tomography (µCT) has the advantage of non-destructive measurements, but the beam-hardening effect with polychromatic x-rays is a major drawback. To date, no study has validated µCT against TMR. The objective of this study was to validate µCT measurements of enamel lesions under various x-ray conditions and software beam-hardening correction (BHC) against TMR. Human molars with natural white-spot lesions were scanned for 5 min by µCT at 100 kV in different conditions: 50 µA (0.5-mm Al filter), 165 µA (0.5-mm Al/0.3-mm Cu), and 200 µA (0.5-mm Al/0.4-mm Cu), with or without BHC. Grayscale values were converted into mineral density values using phantoms. Thin sections at the same positions were then prepared for TMR. Lesion depth (LD; µm) and mineral loss (ΔZ; vol%µm) were compared between µCT and TMR by Pearson’s correlations. µCT measurements correlated well with TMR under all conditions (p < 0.001, r > 0.86 for LD and ΔZ), except for 0.5-mm Al without BHC (p > 0.05). Even without BHC, combined Al/Cu filters successfully reduced the beam-hardening effect. µCT can be used as a non-destructive alternative to TMR with comparable parameters for the study of enamel lesions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mineral density (MD) assessment of teeth is important in demineralization and remineralization studies, providing an insight into the changes associated with spatial distribution of minerals within the lesions. The use of radiographic methods has been recommended to quantify MD (Ten Bosch and Angmar-Mansson, 1991). Currently, transverse microradiography (TMR) is considered as the gold standard two-dimensional (2D) technique for the determination of MD in vitro. However, TMR requires destructive sample preparation, and longitudinal analysis on the same lesion involves preparation of fragile single sections, which may be lost in the course of a study (Mellberg et al., 1986; Thomas et al., 2006).

X-ray computed tomography (CT) is a non-destructive imaging method where individual projections (radiographs) are used to reconstruct a three-dimensional (3D) structure. Micro-focus x-ray CT (µCT) uses a focused beam providing higher resolution on smaller samples in vitro (Elliott and Dover, 1982). The method has been frequently used in experiments exploring bone (Schweizer et al., 2007; Burghardt et al., 2008; Nazarian et al., 2008) and is a promising technique for the assessment of tooth MD (Kinney et al., 1995; Anderson et al., 1996; Davis and Wong, 1996; Lo et al., 2010; Hamba et al., 2011; Cochrane et al., 2012).

The beam-hardening effect caused by the polychromatic x-ray has been shown to be a major drawback (Mulder et al., 2004; Zou et al., 2011). In short, the low-energy photons are eliminated from the beam at a faster rate than the higher-energy levels. Consequently, the beam becomes more penetrating, or harder, as it traverses through matter, creating an apparent higher attenuation near the periphery of a homogeneous sample (Jennings, 1988; Kovacs et al., 2009; Hamba et al., 2011). Several approaches that minimize inaccuracies arising from the beam-hardening effect have been recommended; in particular, beam filtrations or pre-hardening with attenuating “hardware” metal filters (aluminum, copper, or brass) (Jennings, 1988; Meganck et al., 2009) during the scanning, “software” beam-hardening correction (BHC) during reconstruction (Burghardt et al., 2008), and MD calibration have been suggested (Wong et al., 2004; Zou et al., 2011). Nevertheless, a standard metal filter for effective correction of beam-hardening on enamel has not been introduced (Zou et al., 2011).

A similar trend has been observed between the linear attenuation coefficient of µCT and lesion depth (LD) of TMR in enamel subsurface lesions (Lo et al., 2010). The polychromatic µCT potentially provides a user-friendly and cost-effective laboratory method for the evaluation of lesions (Zou et al., 2011); however, there appears to be no published study evaluating the correlations in lesion parameters such as LD and mineral loss (ΔZ) between µCT and TMR.

Enamel white-spots are natural demineralized active or inactive lesions that have a surface layer and cover a wide range of LD and ΔZ (Cochrane et al., 2012), making them suitable substrates for quantitative comparison in the lesion parameters. The objective of this study was to validate µCT measurements of white-spot lesions in enamel under various x-ray conditions and BHC against TMR.

sec.title: Tooth Preparation
sec.p: Fifteen non-cavitated natural white-spot lesions were investigated on mid-facial enamel surfaces of six human third molars from patients aged 21 to 32 yrs. The teeth were extracted as part of orthodontic treatment and used after the individuals’ informed consent was obtained according to a protocol approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee, Tokyo Medical and Dental University (No. 725). The teeth were cleaned and stored in distilled water at 4°C. Two positioning holes were made by a diamond bur (440SS ISO # 010, Shofu, Kyoto, Japan) adjacent to each lesion; these holes helped to determine the exact location of the lesion during µCT and TMR (Figs. 1A, 1D).

caption.p: Representative 3D reconstruction of 2 teeth at slices with a shallow lesion (A) or a deep lesion (D) in enamel by µCT. 2D µCT and TMR images show shallow lesion (B) and deep lesion (E) in enamel. The µCT image was averaged over 100 µm, and the corresponding TMR image was obtained with a 100-µm-thick physical slice at the same location as the µCT volume of interest (VOI). The small boxes indicate the position of the 200 × 1,200 µm2 (width × depth) region over which the mineral content was plotted in each lesion. Arrows point to the positioning holes in µCT and TMR images. The graphs present mineral density profiles of shallow (C) and deep (F) lesions by µCT and TMR under various scanning conditions.

sec.title: µCT Scanning
sec.p: Each whole-tooth sample was mounted on the computer-controlled turntable of a µCT system (InspeXio SMX-100CT; Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) so that the x-ray beam was perpendicular to the facial surface of the tooth. Three different metal filters were placed in front of the detector for hardware beam-hardening correction: (1) 0.5-mm-thick aluminum (0.5Al), (2) 0.5-mm-thick aluminum and 0.3-mm-thick copper (0.5Al/0.3Cu), and (3) 0.5-mm-thick aluminum and 0.4-mm-thick copper (0.5Al/0.4Cu). Each of these filters was used with or without software beam-hardening correction (BHC) (Table 1). X-rays were generated at 100 kV with different currents for each filter, so that the intensity of the x-ray beam at the detector, after passing through air and the filter, ranged from 75 to 90% of the source intensity (Table 1). To minimize ring artifacts, air calibration of the detector was carried out prior to each scanning. 12-frame averaging was also applied in the acquisition phase to improve the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) (Neves Ade et al., 2010).

caption.p: µCT Conditions at Each Metal Filter

sec.p: Each tooth was rotated 360° within an integration time of 5 min. The distances from the x-ray source to the sample and to the detector were 74 mm and 300 mm, respectively. Data were acquired as 500 TIFF files for reconstruction of the 3D image of the coronal part with 1,024 × 1,024-pixel resolution and 12.5-µm isotropic voxel sizes.

For BHC, an aluminum wedge (2.68 gAlcm–3 density) with 5 steps (2-, 5-, 10-, 20-, and 40-mm-thick) was scanned under each condition, from which a beam-hardening curve was obtained and fitted to the data points as previously described (Neves Ade et al., 2010).

For MD calibration, a series of mineral reference phantoms was also scanned (Hamba et al., 2011), which included 3 hydroxyapatite (HAp) disks (Ratoc, Tokyo, Japan) with different concentrations (0.20, 0.50, and 0.70 gHApcm–3) of HAp crystals embedded in epoxy resin, and a pure HAp disk (3.16 gHApcm–3) (Cellyard; Hoya, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: µCT Image Analysis
sec.p: 3D image analysis software (TRI/3D-BON; Ratoc), originally developed for bone morphometry (Binte Anwar et al., 2007), was used for visualization and quantitative measurements. Grayscale values were converted into MD values (gHApcm–3) with a linear calibration curve based on the grayscale values obtained from the mineral phantoms for each of the 6 conditions (linear regression, R2 = 0.98 - 0.99). Subsequently, a 3 × 3 median filter was applied to suppress image noise (Skinner et al., 2009; Neves Ade et al., 2010). Mean MD values were calculated and plotted against depth in a volume of interest (VOI) of 100 × 200 × 1,200 µm3 (thickness × width × depth) determined according to the positioning holes. We converted the MD profile to relative MD profile by assuming sound enamel consisting of a maximum MD of 87 vol% (Angmar et al., 1963; de Josselin de Jong et al., 1987; Kitasako et al., 2012). Lesion depth (LD; µm) and mineral loss (ΔZ; vol%µm) were calculated from the relative MD profiles, with the reference point of the depth axis (0 µm) set at the axial position of the apparent enamel lesion surface. We calculated ΔZ from the profiles on each sample by subtracting the area under the curve from the area of sound enamel assumed before demineralization occurred. LD was recorded as the depth of the region where the mineral content reached 95% of the maximum MD (Arends et al., 1987).

sec.title: Transverse Microradiography Measurements
sec.p: After µCT scanning, the samples were dehydrated in an ascending ethanol series (25%-100%), embedded in epoxy resin, precisely sectioned across the reference landmarks of the lesion with a low-speed diamond saw (Isomet; Buehler, Lake Bluff, IL, USA) and hand-polished with silicon-carbide paper up to #1200 under water-cooling to a uniform thickness of 100 µm. The slices were mounted on plastic templates along with an aluminum step-wedge for MD calibration. Radiographs were taken on high-resolution plates (HRP-SN-2; Konica Minolta, Tokyo, Japan) with a Cu-Kα x-ray source (SRO-M50; Sofron, Tokyo, Japan) operating at 25 kV and 4 mA for 15 min, and scanned as 8-bit digital images by means of a CCD camera attached to a stereo microscope (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan). Mean MD profiles were plotted in a region of interest (ROI) of 200 × 1,200 µm2 (width × depth) in the center of lesion with image-analysis software (ImageJ; NIH, Bethesda, MD, USA). In this manner, the ROI on the TMR section matched the VOI analyzed by µCT (Fig. 1). LD (µm) and ΔZ (vol%µm) were calculated from the plots in the same manner as described above.

sec.title: Statistical Comparisons
sec.p: Correlations in LD and ΔZ between µCT and TMR were examined by Pearson’s correlation. In case a significant correlation was found, multiple ANCOVA comparisons with Bonferroni correction were used to find the µCT conditions which resulted in a standard linear relationship (Y = aX + b, where a = 1 and b = 0) with TMR for both LD and ΔZ. For this purpose, first the slope and then the intercepts were investigated. These analyses were performed with statistical software (SPSS; Chicago, IL, USA) at significance level of α = 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Typical 2D images and MD profiles for shallow and deep lesions are shown in Fig. 1. The profiles obtained by µCT and TMR measurements visually appeared to be similar in shape, except for the 0.5Al groups, which typically showed remarkably intensified MD at the surface layer. LD ranged from 150 to 950 µm (average, 591 ± 247 µm), and ΔZ ranged from 4,000-33,000 vol%µm (average, 12,051 ± 6,100 vol%µm) with TMR.

There were strong correlations in both LD and ΔZ between TMR and µCT, except for the 0.5Al filter without BHC, which showed no significant correlation (p > 0.05), and was therefore excluded from further analysis (Table 2). ANCOVA revealed that the regression lines were not significantly different from each other and from (Y = X) for LD. In ΔZ, the 0.5Al with BHC group showed a significant intercept (p < 0.01), while the 0.5Al/0.3Cu and 0.5Al/0.4Cu groups showed no significant difference in slope and intercept from the expected Y = X, regardless of the BHC (p > 0.05 for both slope and intercept) (Fig. 2).

caption.p: Correlations of Lesion Depth and Mineral Loss in µCT against TMR

fn.p: Linear relationship not significantly different from Y = X (ANCOVA, p > 0.05).

caption.p: Correlations of lesion depth (LD; µm) and mineral loss (ΔZ; vol%µm) between µCT and TMR for 0.5-mm Al (A, B), 0.5-mm Al+0.3-mm Cu (C, D), and 0.5-mm Al+0.4-mm Cu (E, F) filters, respectively. The dotted line indicates the standard Y = X linear relationship. No significant correlation was found between µCT and TMR for 0.5-mm Al filter without software beam-hardening correction (BHC).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: TMR is considered as the gold standard technique for the determination of MD. However, this method requires sample embedding, drying, and precise sectioning, followed by development and digitization of the micrographs (Damen et al., 1997). µCT can provide 3D images and MD profiles without these time-consuming procedures. Moreover, artifacts resulting from thin-section preparation, including overlapping of microstructural features or sloped edges (Thomas et al., 2006) and shrinkage of the tissue due to drying of the sample, particularly with samples having a low mineral concentration (van Strijp et al., 1995), can be avoided. Standard calculations for LD and ΔZ established for TMR (Angmar et al., 1963) were applied to µCT MD profiles to facilitate direct and meaningful comparison between the two techniques in the same lesions.

The selection of metal filters to reduce the µCT beam-hardening effect in this study involved 3 combinations based on previous studies. Al filters (Clementino-Luedemann and Kunzelmann, 2006; Lo et al., 2010) and combination filters, including Al and Cu (Neves Ade et al., 2010), have been suggested for beam-hardening correction. The use of BHC has also been recommended (Clementino-Luedemann and Kunzelmann, 2006; Neves Ade et al., 2010). A combination of Al/Cu plates as in the current study was found to be the most effective in reducing cupping artifacts (Meganck et al., 2009). In pilot experiments, whole-tooth samples were scanned under various filters, and grayscale values across a coronal sound enamel-dentin section were plotted. It was found that the results of µCT were comparable with those of TMR for those filters with relatively smooth and flat line-plots on sound enamel (Appendix Fig.). In fact, analysis of previous data has shown that the spectrum transmitted by a 0.1-mm-thick Cu filter is very close to that of a 3.7-mm Al filter (Jennings, 1988). Nonetheless, a reduction in the contrast and SNR of µCT images was noted with stronger filters, which could be explained by the fact that the number of photons at the lower energy levels decreased with filtration (Meganck et al., 2009). In the present study, the current was increased for stronger filters, so that we could obtain adequate photon statistics at the detector while using the same integration time across the groups.

It is noteworthy that the 2D TMR image had a smoother appearance and more details visualized compared with a 2D image obtained by averaging several slices over the same VOI in µCT. Generally, noise is inherently present in any µCT slices; in addition to the metal filter, the SNR is also related to resolution, hardware capability, and scanning time (Neves Ade et al., 2010). The scanning time of 5 min for a whole tooth is substantially shorter compared with that reported in previous studies which applied integration times of up to 2 days (Wong et al., 2004; Cochrane et al., 2012); nevertheless, good correlations were found between µCT and TMR under all scanning conditions, except for 0.5Al without BHC. In this group, MD was strongly overestimated at the superficial area (Appendix Table); the beam-hardening effect influenced the shapes of profiles, resulting in significant errors in calculation of LD, especially in shallow lesions, and ΔZ. BHC could improve the profiles of this group, so that both LD and ΔZ correlated with TMR; however, ANCOVA showed that ΔZ values in this group were overestimated by an intercept when compared with the expected linear regression. In contrast, significant correlation in ΔZ between the µCT and TMR in the 0.5Al/0.3Cu or 0.5Al/0.4Cu group suggested that the beam-hardening effect was corrected effectively by these filters. The resulting µCT MD profiles corresponded closely with those of TMR. While the minimum MD of the lesion in these µCT groups showed values similar to those of TMR (Appendix Table), the maximum MD at the surface layer in µCT scanning was still higher than that calculated by TMR (Appendix Table). Interestingly, the maxima with 0.5Al/0.4Cu filters (mean, 90%-94% of sound enamel maximum MD) corresponded to the values reported in the literature (Wong et al., 2004; Meyer-Lueckel et al., 2007; Cochrane et al., 2012); therefore, in the case where MD is to be compared among different layers within enamel lesions (i.e., surface layer and lesion body), such strong filter is recommended. The surface layer MD did not significantly affect the standard correlation with TMR with the combination Al/Cu filters, indicating the validity of the µCT results with regard to mineral gain/loss in the whole lesion with this type of filter. Selection of the metal filter depends on the radiopacity of the substrate; further research is necessary to investigate the scanning conditions suitable for dentin MD assessment by µCT with or without the overlying enamel.

With a combination of Al and Cu filters, and regardless of software beam-hardening correction, 3D µCT-based measurements of mineral loss and lesion depth of natural enamel white-spot lesions corresponded well with those parameters derived from TMR, thus validating this technique as an effective alternative for non-destructive quantitative demineralization and remineralization laboratory studies.
